comment:
Ah, my most distinguished and refined compatriots, gather 'round as I regale you with a tale of utmost horror and revulsion. One had the grievous misfortune of sampling what our uncouth transatlantic cousins have the temerity to refer to as ‚Äúchawklit.‚Äù Upon the merest taste, I was struck as if by a thunderbolt of sheer gastronomic terror, akin to nibbling upon a bar concocted from the very essence of regurgitated muck!

It is, without a shadow of a doubt, an affront to the noble lineage of British confectionery, an institution as venerable as Her Majesty herself. One's senses were assailed by this so-called chocolate, leaving me in a state of profound distress, akin to discovering that one‚Äôs afternoon tea had been steeped with dishwater!

Even the most ancient and rock-like fruitcake of me Great-Uncle Percival, which has survived unscathed since the days of the Boer War, would be a delight of epicurean splendor by comparison! The impudence of it all, the gall! It is an insult of the highest order to all that is sacred and delicious.

By the whiskers of me beloved Persian cat, Lady Fluffington, even she would turn up her exquisitely royal nose at such a disgrace. It beggars belief that any creature, human or otherwise, could endure such a culinary catastrophe. The audacity to call it chocolate is beyond the pale. It‚Äôs a travesty of the highest magnitude, an abomination against the very essence of cocoa itself. Truly, it is a sign of the decline of civilization! Good heavens, I must take to me fainting couch!

comment:
Bournville is a model village on the southwest side of Birmingham, England, founded by the Quaker Cadbury family for employees at its Cadbury's factory and designed to be a "garden" (or "model") village  where the sale of alcohol was forbidden.

Cadbury's is well known for chocolate products ‚Äì including a dark chocolate bar branded Bournville.

Historically in northern Worcestershire, it is also a ward within the council constituency of Selly Oak and home to the Bournville Centre for Visual Arts.

Bournville is known as one of the most desirable areas to live in the UK; research by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation in 2003 found that it was "one of the nicest places to live in Britain".


History

Originally the area that was to become Bournville consisted of a few scattered farmsteads and cottages, linked by winding country lanes, with the only visual highlight being Bournbrook Hall, which was built during the Georgian era.

The bluebell glades of Stock Wood were said to be a relic of the Forest of Arden and there are Roman remains nearby.

Though Selly Manor and Minworth Greaves date back to the 14th century or earlier, they were each moved to Bournville in the 20th century, and are operated as a museum.


Cadbury

Having taken over their father John Cadbury's expanding business in 1861, the Quakers George and Richard Cadbury needed to move their cocoa and chocolate factory from Bridge Street in central Birmingham to a greenfield site to allow for expansion.

Cadbury were reliant on the canals for milk delivery, and on the railways for cocoa deliveries from the ports of London and Southampton.

They therefore needed a site which was undeveloped and had easy access to both canal and rail.

The brothers noticed the proposed development of the Birmingham West Suburban Railway, which would extend from central Birmingham south along the path of the Worcester and Birmingham Canal into the then green fields of southern Birmingham and the villages of northern Worcestershire.

In 1879, they moved their business to Bournbrook Hall, 4 miles (6.4 km) to the south of Birmingham.

The location was chosen as it was regarded as cleaner, healthier and more amenable to longer-term expansion plans.

Although rural, it was also already serviced by the new Stirchley Street railway station, which itself was located right next to the canal.

The Cadburys named the area 'Bournville' after a local river named The Bourn (not to be confused with Bourn Brook, a similarly named local river for which the neighbourhood of Bournbrook is named); with 'ville' being French for 'town'; this set Bournville apart from the local area.

Then the Cadburys began to develop their factory in the new suburb.

Loyal and hard-working workers were treated with great respect and relatively high wages and good working conditions; Cadbury also pioneered pension schemes, joint works committees and a full staff medical service.

In 1893, George Cadbury bought 120 acres (0.5 km2) of land close to the works and planned, at his own expense, a model village which would "alleviate the evils of modern, more cramped living conditions".

By 1900, the estate included 313 cottages and houses set on 330 acres (1.3 km2) of land, and many more similar properties were built in the years leading up to the First World War, with smaller developments taking place later on in the 20th century.

These almost 'Arts and Crafts' houses were traditional in design but with large gardens and modern interiors, and were designed by the resident architect William Alexander Harvey.

These designs became a blueprint for many other model village estates around Britain.

It is also noteworthy that, because George Cadbury was a temperance Quaker, no public houses have ever been built in Bournville; however, since the late 1940s, there has been a licensed members' bar at Rowheath Pavilion.

The Cadburys were particularly concerned with the health and fitness of their British workforce, incorporating park and recreation areas into the Bournville village plans and encouraging swimming, walking and indeed all forms of outdoor sports.

In the early 1920s, extensive open lands were purchased at Rowheath and laid to football and hockey pitches together with a grassed running track.

Rowheath Pavilion was designed and built in accordance with the instructions of George Cadbury and opened in July 1924.

At that time, it served as the clubhouse and changing rooms for the acres of sports playing fields, several bowling greens, a fishing lake and an outdoor swimming lido, a natural mineral spring forming the source for the lido's healthy waters.

The Rowheath Pavilion itself, which still exists, was used for balls and dinners and the whole area was specifically for the benefit of the Cadbury workers and their families with no charges for the use of any of the sporting facilities by Cadbury employees or their families.

The lido was eventually closed in the 1970s after complaints of noise disturbance were made by residents of the newly built Oak Farm estate, coupled with new and stringent health and safety regulations relating to outdoor public swimming facilities.

Cadbury's also built the Bournville indoor swimming baths on Bournville Lane (separate buildings for 'girls' and men), the Valley pool boating lake and the picturesque cricket pitch adjacent to the factory site, that was made famous as the picture on boxes of Milk Tray chocolates throughout the 1950s and early 1960s.

In 1900, the Bournville Village Trust was set up to formally control the development of the estate, independently of George Cadbury or the Cadbury company.

Elizabeth Cadbury succeeded her husband as chair of the Bournville Village Trust in 1922.

The trust focused on providing schools, hospitals, museums, public baths and reading rooms.

As Bournville is a conservation area, another job of the Bournville Village Trust is to accept or reject plans for building extension and modification.

An almost campus feel evolved, with a triangular village green, infant and junior schools, the School of Art and the Day Continuation School (originally intended for young Cadbury employees) and a host of events such as f√™tes and Maypole dances.

The carillon and a Quaker meeting house are also beside the village green.

The trust continues to exercise an international influence on housing and town planning generally.

Now containing 7,800 homes on 1,000 acres (4 km2) of land with 100 acres (0.4 km2) of parks and open spaces, Bournville remains a popular residential area of Birmingham.

Cadbury is still one of Birmingham's main employers, and continues to make chocolate products.

The dark chocolate Bournville Plain is now manufactured in France and sold in the UK.

Cadbury also named their brand of malted drinks Bournvita after Bournville.

Cadbury World is now established here.

comment: If you say that liquid milk and evaporated milk taste about the same, then your taste buds are almost gone. Also, I tried once a Hersey's chocolate bar and it shouldn't be even allowed to be called chocolate. This is definitely a way to brainwash U.S.A. citizens into believing that Hersey's good and cheap chocolate. Cheap? Maybe, though the price is significant higher when sold here in Europe. Good? Absolutely definitely not. Real good chocolate main ingredients are cocoa and sugar and dark chocolate goes up to 70% - 80% cocoa (and some even higher). You also compared with a wrong brand. U.K. is not part of the E.U. anymore and the E.U. dictates that you may call something only milk chocolate with a cocoa percentage of at least 25% (otherwise it may not be called milk chocolate, exception is white chocolate with 0% cocao and at least 20% cocao butter) and pure chocolate must have at least 35%. Also, all factory made big brand chocolate have preservings, have quite mix of good and less good chocolate beans and have undergone too much conching . If you want to taste real chocolate, you should checkout the following brands: Argencove, Labooko, Friis Holm, Chocolate tree, Foundry and Ritual. There are likely more but it's a start.

comment:
All these people talking about Cadbury are missing the point. Cadbury was Hershey's biggest competitor in the states. His methods and business model were designed specifically to beat them. They were not claiming that Cadbury is Europe's chocolate, just that it is the European brand that competed with Hershey in the states as well as was (and still is) the one with which most Americans are familiar. 

Also, I'm really loving the self-assured attitude of the Europeans and ex-pats in these comments. I have also been to Europe and seen and tasted some awful food there. Maybe, just maybe, you think your food is so much better because you are used to it? This reminds me of James May claiming on Top Gear that "Mexicans can't do food." comment:
About "Uncle Milty"...  Obviously Cheddar has THE WRONG VERSION (2:19) of his story. Milton Hershey went to Europe on a several month vacation tour (he was already making caramel as The Lancaster Caramel Co. by then) and found ou19t about a CHOCOLATE BAR MAKING MACHINE already developed in Switzerland years earlier. 

Since nobody else had anything like it Stateside he decided to buy and import one of those machines for his factory. When he came back to Pennsylvania he and his people developed (after quite a lot of failed formulas) THE HERSHEY MILK CHOCOLATE BAR in 1896 as the first US-made chocolate bar.

His chocolate sold so much he decided to sell his caramel business to go full force into it.

Hershey didn't invent the chocolate bar as it was already invented in Europe.

Another thing... Cheddar forgets to even mention Uncle Milty's real competitor (and partner for years) Forrest Mars, of M&M's fame. When Mars found in Spain during their Civil War in the later 1930's some particular "chocolate buttons" that didn't melt in the sun. Brought those Stateside and covered them with a candy coating. 

But when WWII started sugar and chocolate were rationed in US and both Hershey and Mars got US War Department contracts for putting chocolate foods into rations, so they made an agreement for Hershey to provide Mars with chocolate so neither supplies of both companies would be cut off. M&M's and other Mars confectionery products used Hershey's chocolate until like the 1960's.

comment: I came over to the states from Wales  a few years ago, and fancied a nice bar of chocolate, so went down to the hotel shop and bought a standard bar of Hershey's. What could possibly go wrong? I'd heard of Hershey's from TV although at the time it wasn't sold where I lived. Well, I'm sure you know the feeling when you bite into something and it's not the taste you were expecting! My eyes widened and my mouth went into gag mode! I forced the first bite down eventually, but my brain refused to believe what had just happened, I assumed my taste buds hadn't woken up or something as there is no way a chocolate bar should taste the way I'd just imagined! so I took another bite, and holy shit! This chocolate really does taste of puke. I had lots of fun offering a chunk of Hershey's to my friends who were with me on the trip, just to see their reaction! We assumed that my bar was part of a dodgy batch. I know this post reads like I'm dissing American chocolate, ok I am a bit üòÇ, but if that is the taste you're used to then you obviously won't get the viseral reaction I had. comment: British milk chocolate (which Cheddar compares with Hershey) isn't good chocolate even compared with British dark chocolate, let alone Belgian or Swiss chocolate. It is interesting that for decades Rowntrees' Kit-Kat was only produced as milk-chocolate coated wafers. It was never very pleasant and melts easily in warm weather. When Rowntrees announced it was going to make Kit-Kat bars with dark chocolate and other flavours, there was cynicism that the traditional Kit-Kat was so established in Britain that other varieties would not be accepted. The reverse proved to be the case: the dark-chocolate Kit-Kat and the mint-flavoured dark Kit-Kat bars are much more pleasant to eat. The milk-chocolate version may appeal to children, but for adults the  dark chocolate covered wafer bars are much to be preferred. Why did it take so long for Rowntrees to produce dark-chocolate Kit-Kat bars?

comment:
Don't think ALL European chocolate taste the same!! Different countries have their own brands, with their own recipies.
In Sweden and Norway we have what in Sweden is called Marabou and in Norway Freia. The original is Freia, which owner 1916 started a new wing of Freia in Sweden, called it Marabou, and started making chocolate by the same recipies as in Norway.
Nowadays they work as different companies.

Marabou mj√∂lkchoklad (Marabou milkchocolate) is the leading product in Sweden, but there're many, many different kinds in different ways, from "old fashion" chocolate bars to assorted chocolate creames. The Aladdin chocolate box is a must in Swedish homes during Christmas.
I believe the Daim bar is sold in many countries.

In the early eighties I spend some time in the USA, grooming harness horses, together with many more Swedes. Occasionly we had presents sent from Sweden, containing Marabou chocolate and Swedish coffee. When those packages arrived we had a lot of American friends üòÇüòÇüòÇ, though they prefered the Swedish both chocolate and coffee.
(Sorry, but at least in the eighties American coffee was TERRIBLE. Compared to Swedish it tasted like the coffee beans were toasted to charcoal, grinded and measured 1/2 teaspoon / cup. ü§ÆCriminal. üôÑ üòÇ
Love you anyway, I only met really nice people!

comment:
THAT IS UNTRUE!!! There are NO preservatives used in European chocolate. It's stable because of its low water activity, careful balance between the fatty acids and great-quality raw materials. There are no preservatives that can legally be added to chocolate in the EU.
Also, what she says about the cocoa content is WRONG! EU chocolate does contain a lot more cocoa by LAW, namely a minimum 35%, made up of at least 18% cocoa butter AND at least 14% fat-free cocoa mass. This is A LOT more than the US, which she says has a minimum of just 10%.
Disclaimer: I'm a EU food law expert (seriously. It's my day job.)

comment:
Finally an answer! When I went to the US for the first time, I tried a number of different brands of chocolate bars from the local CVS and Target. I was left wondering why anyone would eat them as they all tasted terrible; prompting me to check the expiry date every time. Even the really cheap ‚Äòeaster egg‚Äô chocolate that you get here in the UK, beat any chocolate I ate in the US, a run for it‚Äôs money. I would recommend Americans to try chocolate from ‚ÄòMilka‚Äô, it‚Äôs a German brand; some of the best tasting chocolate I have ever had. Give it a try if you get the chance, you can find it in most European countries when you visit. 

What I really found odd - more so than the chocolate - was Twizzlers. They have little to no taste and you get a waxy or plastic aftertaste, strange as people seemed to really like them. Swedish Fish are awesome though!

A few years ago, the company was bought by America‚Äôs Kraft Corporation and they moved production to Poland. As a result, Cadbury is seeing far wider exposure in mainland Europe and the US.  Apparently, Hershey‚Äôs have rights to produce Cadbury products in the US, but with a different recipe, so Cadbury chocolates UK/Europe can‚Äôt sell to the US market. So Americans will need to import from Europe to see what they‚Äôre missing!

comment: Western Europeans hate Root Beer but love Dr. Pepper. Many of them love peanut butter and reese's peanut butter cups. Any new food to them they must smell it before they try it. And I mean really smell it. If they don't like the smell they won't eat it. If it's a different color from what they are used to they won't eat it. When I was stationed in the Netherlands I made an entire Fajita Dinner (Fajitas, Spanish Rice, Refried beans with green chillies, flan for desert) for my Girlfriend and her family. They had never had cilantro before, didn't like the smell and wouldn't eat any of it. If I smelled stuff before I ate it I wouldn't eat half the stuff I eat. I made my Mom's Golden Potato Salad  ( Eggs, Potatoes, Mayonnaise, Sliced Black Olives and enough French's American Mustard to turn it a nice creamy buttercup yellow [diced onions optional]) in the Balkans. Because it wasn't White like every other potato salad they wouldn't eat it. The Dutch above the rivers and the Balkans people do not like mixed flavors so Chinese restaurants do not last long. To mess with the Bosnians and Kosovars we would feed them honey roasted peanuts. :)

comment: why can't chocolate just be chocolate, milk just be milk, sweet just be sweet, salty just be salty? I hate mixing of flavors that serves to simply cover up the inadequacies of a recipe or of ingredient quality. WHY would you want chocolate to taste bitter or sour? How disgusting! I don't understand why people still like to eat pickled, soured, salted and smoked stuff. Those are all very unhealthy methods of preservation and were used when we had no freezers or fast transportation. These days frozen fruits or vegetables are no worse, or even better, than fresh. Fish can be frozen very successfully too, as can just about anything else. Very few things are truly ruined by freezing. Chocolate can be kept in a refrigerator, which works very well to keep it fresh for a long time. Nothing should be altered chemically for the purposes of preservation. Make stuff closer to home. Give your business to local chocolate shops. Yeah, it's a bit more expensive. SO DON'T EAT SO MUCH OF IT. It should be a rare treat. Why SHOULD chocolate be treated any differently than a rare treat. If you can afford it then eat it often, if not, eat it rarely. You'll only be healthier for it. Nothing wrong with wealthy people affording more expensive fancier stuff. Usually it's less healthy anyway. Don't alter stuff to make it worse tasting. THAT'S DUMB.

I am sure a lot of people do not mind if it is a bit bitter. Very dark chocolate tend to be a bit bitter and some see this even as a high quality and you're having a refined taste. comment: Very interesting. Have often wondered about this. As a European I'd always known of Hershey's from TV and film so naturally looked forward to trying some for the first time when a friend bought some back the the US. Until then, I'd wondered that, if they were such a big brand, why they'd never broken into the European market. First horrible bite and I had my answer! Not only was it so different to real chocolate, it may as well have been in a completely deferent food group, but the texture was also off; furry instead of silky. It was like eating the contents of a vacuum bag, leaving me genuinely perplexed as to why America, I land known for its food excess, would tolerate something so bland and nasty... and unlike actual chocolate! I see that they just were never really given a choice. To this end though, I've also seen Americans eat European chocolate and say it's too sweet. Guess it's down to what one is used to. Since then I have seen Hershey's for sale in the UK. It always seems to be on discount offer. I would never buy it or know anyone that would. Yuk; brown furry curdled cheese... you can keep it America!

comment:
I called bullcrap on this about a decade ago and asked someone who went to the US to bring me some chocolate of the better kind.
I ate all of it from Hershey's, Almond Joy, Mounds and Reese's, and all I can say is that I would rather chew drywall or cardboard. It's absolutely awful. I sadly failed to put my hands on a butterfinger or a whatchamacallit, but I'm just going to assume they aren't so good either. 

I did the same with cheese, fruit, beer and jerky as well, and my conclusion as a man of refined tastes is that American chocolate is garbage, American cheese is not even cheese, American fruit is basically water with texture, American beer is what I imagine my piss tastes like after having drunk actual beer, and American jerky is amazing and I'm still trying to recreate it after a decade. Never could get that meaty, spicy, orange-y taste just right. I just know it probably has something to do with anise. 

Anyway, my conclusion is that Europeans(that's not a thing by the way. There's no such thing as an "european man") hate American chocolate because we managed to retain our tastebuds. 
I try my best to be objective, but there's no way anyone would ever prefer american chocolate to the real thing.

comment: I‚Äôm an American, born and raised, and Hershey‚Äôs....any chocolate from a convenience store isn‚Äôt worth it. It‚Äôs incredibly acidic and burns the inside of your mouth. American chocolate can be amazing, but you gotta know what you‚Äôre looking for. Instead of bothering with mass manufacturers, find a local chocolatier. Hu chocolate is amazing, and it‚Äôs based out of NY. Endangered Species Chocolate is incredible, and it‚Äôs based out of Indiana. Theo chocolate is based out of Seattle. Chocolove is based out of Colorado. All of those can be found at either Whole Foods or Publix. What you really need is someone dedicated to making quality chocolate, and you need to experiment so you can find the good stuff, just like with anything else. A dear friend of mine was only eating Hershey‚Äôs, and I was low key a little grossed out, and I subsequently showed him a high quality milk chocolate and he‚Äôs never looked back. comment:
I am from Central Illinois, but have traveled in Europe.  I have had quality chocolate, and because of my location am denied quality chocolate.  About twenty years ago, Reuben's Chocolates was open in Champaign, IL, and their chocolate was ported from Belgium.  It had to be refrigerated.  It was perfection, but they retired.  My husband had some chocolate shipped from a store in Chicagoland, but it was also sub par, although they claimed to be Belgium.
So, my longing continues.

As much as I love chocolate,  American chocolate is nasty.  Buy a bar of the basic brands, smell it,  take a  bite and really taste it....it resembles vomit or buttermilk.  This is why American.chocolate companies have to.add all the p.b., nuts, caramel, nouget, etc.  And some has so much wax that it is a crime to call it chocolate.
  Being in a limited area, I only bake with Hershey's Special Dark Chips, but I miss Reuben's Belgium Chocolates and the Chocolates I had when in France.

comment:
I love food, snacks, candy etc and often go out of my way to try to acquire different versions of candies, snacks etc from different countries.
I had a "blind taste test" of chocolates in school with a couple of friends and their teacher (culinary school on top of it all)
Except for the 2 American exchange students(who considered it average chocolate), every one called Hershey "cheap, probably had no real coco in it and almost certainly gone bad" (it was still within best before date) and first tasting Hershey... i had to look at the best before date, and order 3 more just to be sure it had not spoiled in the transport...
I know that some people likes it (you do you, enjoy what you like regardless of what others think of your tastes) but even the taught of Hershey leaves a bad taste in my mouth...
The only worse(imho) chocolate i ever tasted was some 100% artificial "chocolate bar" (was supposed to taste like milk chocolate) from France that just tasted like dirt...
/How ever to Hersheys credit, their strawberry syrup is imo the best in the world.

comment:
In my experience, it's simply because our chocolate is better...

I have sent boxes of candy across the ocean to friends in the US i've met through gaming, and they've sent me boxes back, and with the 30 or so different people i've had try Norwegian chocolate, the one thing they all have in common is sentences like "omg! we don't have anything like this, this is amazing" and usually want information on how to order it.

Even had a couple get annoyed after the fact that because they said [US] chocolate didn't fulfill cravings anymore because all they can think about is Norwegian chocolate. 

Though personally i think Belgian milk chocolate has us beat by a mile.

If anyone's curious and/or want to order and try some themselves, usually isn't too hard to find, the most popular ones were "Freia melkesjokolade" (Freia is the brand) "Freia M" and the biggest favorite is "Nidar Smash" though that ones more of a mix between chocolate and corn chips, so just google any of those if you're curious

Most Swiss, German French and Italian chocolate to name a few are generally much higher quality. I would say a manufacturer such as lindt is a very good quality that is available throughout Europe. The Nestl√© chocolate manufactured in Europe is also a good quality. Toblerone is ok but owned by Kraft, the same as cadburys. Personally I like Aldi chocolate. They do 3 different qualities under different brand names and are all good and reasonably priced.

comment: When I was a kid I lived in America and I loved the candy there I could not get enough of it. Today I am living in my birth country of Norway. I love the candy here but miss the candy in America so I order it online. I think the reason for the taste difference is because there are a lot of ingredients that are allowed in America that are banned in Europe. Like high fructose corn syrup that you Americans use in soda instead of sugar. Here in Europe, all soda is made with sugar and not GMO produced high fructose corn syrup. The other thing that's different in America is McDonald's. Here in Norway McDonald's french fries are made with 3 ingredients and 3 ingredients only. That being, potatoes, oil, and salt when in America McDonald's french fries are made with the same ingredients but with 50+ other additives that don't need to be in them. Because if you took American McDonald's french fries and left them out for 2 years they would look the same as when you bought them. Unlike here in Norway the same fries would have grown mold after 7 days. Me personally, would never like to eat something that doesn't grow mold after a while. Because if mold doesn't want to grow on it then my body wouldn't want it either.

comment: Thank you for the video. Although I'm sure the same is true in America, there's a demarcation between chocolate brands, like Cadbury, and Hershey, that substitute vegetable fat for cocoa butter in chocolate, and those that do not. Soya Lecithin seems to be everywhere these days, even in Valrhona bars, but most big European brands (including Lindt, Cote'Dor, Milka) do not substitute vegetable fat in their plain chocolate bars; though you might find it incorporated into other chocolate confections, and some cheap brands. Cadbury is very popular in the UK, but it's also very sweet, and a little greasy, with an overpowering vanilla taste: it's still enjoyable, but while there's an arguement for it being a leader in the UK, it seems odd to use it as a benchmark for European Chocolate. This video was very informative about how Hershey's is different, but there is more to the difference in popular European taste.

comment:
Huh. Gotta admit I was never really able to pin down _why_ I (being from Germany) have always felt that American chocolate is terrible. So this might be part of the reason, but it's definitely not the whole story. In addition, US chocolate in general and Hershey's in particular feels like a shovelful of mud in your mouth, compared to European chocolate. It's so coarse and sandy. Some Euro choc is too smooth and mushy (like Lindt) but if I had to blind-test this US stuff, I'd probably have guessed it's some Soviet ersatz product from communist economy of scarcity.

That said, some of the very best chocolate I know is the Swedish brand Marabou. It's the ideal "lagom" choklad - just the right sweetness, cocoa-ness, aroma, "snap" and smoothness. It's part of Mondelez now but the taste still is the real thing. :)

comment:
Thanks for clearing up this mystery for me. I've been wondering why Hershey was so bad since I first tried it during the great marketing disaster of several decades ago, when Hershey tried to take Australia by storm and cost them a small fortune. Back then, most of the chocolate wound up being sold off at ridiculously low prices to unwary customers at the Reject Shop chain.

A correction though - Hershey chocolate doesn't taste like vomit. It tastes just fine while one eats it, but one is then left mystified by the vomit-like aftertaste that follows.

Fortunately, the Hershey chocolate now sold in Australia comes without the vomit aftertaste and makes for a pleasant change to the more typical European type chocolates sold here.
Regards.

comment:
I'm Jamaican-American and ate American chocolates throughout my life. I never really liked them, and eventually stopped eating them completely a year ago. Recently I did a favor for a coworker and he gave me a truffle bar. I didn't want to offend him, so I took it home with the intention of sharing with my sister.

My sister never got to see that bar.  I didn't know chocolate could taste like that. I don't think Hershey's tastes like vomit, but it tastes grossly sweet and a little acidic, and I could only have a few nibbles before being unable to continue. I think I could have eaten a truffle bar the size of my arm that afternoon. And the chocolate inside was liquid! It was delicious!

comment:
Cocoa solids really are an important part of how chocolate tastes. These and are still considered milk chocolate. Dark chocolate bars tend to come in at over 75% cocoa solids, with some reaching 90%.

comment:
Hardly ever seen cadburry or hershes here in the netherlands.
-> as it is imported it is quite expensive, while it is utter trash.
**I'll pick gladly any verkade, milka, or dutch store brand bar over hershes.

Dutch and Belgium chocolate laws were MUCH more strick than eu laws.
as such most what usa sells as chocolate, would to my childhood be "cocao-fantasy" the legal forced name for any "chocolaty product" that does not fit those requirements.

The original dutch/belgium standards were quite tough, originally it was something like :
with white chocolate the minimum must be 60% of coca parts (all cocoa fat)
with milk chocolate the minimum 65%, and a minimum of 15% milkpowder
and with pure chocolate it must be at least 80% (all cococa powder)
**and all fat in them must be cocao fat.
=> proper high quality belgium and dutch chocolate usually still adhers to these old standards.

sadly the eu uniformity indeed has lowered the bar considerably for us dutch and we now have to check lables more to get what WE consider chocolate instead of "cacao fantasy" labled as chocolate because the eu allows it so.

add to that generally usa chocolate contains WAY more sugar than I like in my chocolate.

I prefer mostly white or pure chocolate, milk less so btw.

For pure, I generally look for something with 85% or more cocao powder, and no sugar whatsoever.
for white, I prefer anything with 60% cocao fat and 6% sugar or less, and milkpowder for the rest and less or no other ingredients.
-> if possible I prefer sunflowerlechtine over soylechticine for emulgator.. but thats hard to find these days so thats the one compromise I do usually have to make.

for pure chocolate, there are plenty of 90%+ cocao bars in our stores.. I usually take the 94 or 96% one.. if they have it (98% sometimes also on shelves) the brand Lindt has those very high cocoa content bars.

Let Hersheys melt in your mouth, first off it melts oddly, it's like waxy and oily, kinda thin and not at all creamy, there's some cocoa flavour in there for sure but it just seems oily, and has the bitter butyric acid flavour.
